data.traditional_use: Antihelminthic with ricinus oil
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Externally: infected ulcers; internally: against worms, psoriasis and warts
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Odontadenia macrantha (Roem. & Schult.) Markgr. (Echites grandiflorus G. Mey.)
data.traditional_use: Infusion in water to treat dyspepsia and other digestive disorders, diaphoretic, purgative
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Infusion is used as drastic, to treat dyspepsia and digestive disorders; to treat gastric fever Diaphoretic and purgative
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.vernacular_names: Pé de bezerro, Papagaio, Tagurá, Tinhorão, Tanhorão
data.traditional_use: Cathartic, antihelminthic, against ascarids
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Externally: wounds; Internally: asthma, chlorosis, amenorrhoea, viper bites
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Montrichardia arborescens (L.) Schott (Philodendron arborescens (L.) Kunth, Arum arborescens L.)
data.traditional_use: Healing wounds and ulcers, with fresh juice. Decoction of fresh leaves or dried roots as bath to treat rheumatic pain, testicular and articulation tumours; hydrothorax
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Mucilaginous herb, used to clean wounds, infusion internally to treat blood in urine, diabetes, tumours from erysipelas, herpes and hemoptysis; old wounds can be healed by application of fresh flowers
data.correlated_studies: Antidiabetic, antidermatophytic, antifungal, antimicrobial, diuretic (Tripathi et al., 2010)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Ayapana triplinervis (Vahl) R.M. King & H. Rob. (Eupatorium ayapana Vent.)
data.occurrence: Amazonas, near Sao João do Principe (Rio Negro)
data.traditional_use: Squeezed herb juice or infusion (internally) and pressed herb (externally) against snake bites and as alexipharmacon
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Diuretic, diaphoretic; infusion against diarrhoea (originating from colds)
data.correlated_studies: Antiviral (Rocha Martins et al., 2011); antifungal (Portillo et al., 2001)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Mucilaginous herb used together with indigo, Senna uniflora (Mill.) H.S. Irwin & Barneby (Cassia sericea Sw.), to treat skin ulcers and lymphoedema. Roots are more mucilaginous than the stems
data.correlated_studies: Antiviral (Nakama et al., 2012); antitumour (Nakama et al., 2011); antibacterial (Tobinaga et al., 2009)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Eclipta paludicola Steud. (Eclipta prostrata (L.) L., Eclipta erecta L.)
data.traditional_use: Decoction is used to treat diarrhoea
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Decoction is used in asthenic fevers
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Antisyphilitic, decoction and infusion to treat dysuria, hydrops, water retention; poultice and lotions against syphilitic ulcers
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Used against venereal diseases, mainly inflammations of inguinal lymph, in baths of infusion or decoction for impingement. High doses of decoction cause vomiting and diarrhoea
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Desobstruents, to clean wounds and ulcers, against cutaneous affection; used on anal inflammations
data.correlated_studies: Wound healing (Dash and Murthy, 2011); antibacterial (Nethaji and Manokaran, 2009)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Tree with dried balsam similar to elemi and animes
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Decoction is used to relax sinews
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Seeds are anthelminthic. The inner bark has a balsam that is used to treat wounds from biting insects, mainly Culex penetrans, and malignant ulcers
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Increases diuresis, diaphoresis, wound healing; Rheumatic pain, limb torpor, ulcers, earache
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Jacaratia digitata (Poepp. & Endl.) Solms (Carica digitata Poepp.& Endl.)
data.traditional_use: Poultice to treat wound and ulcer healing
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Poultice to treat wound and ulcer healing
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: The tree has a gum-resin used to treat wound
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Ipomoea pes-caprae (L.) R.Br. (Convolvulus brasiliensis L., Convolvulus maritimus Desr.)
data.traditional_use: Mucilaginous leaves (acres) are used to treat, the effects of colds and chronic gonorrhoea, externally or by mouth. Roots are drastic, thallus and leaves are emollients
data.correlated_studies: Antinociceptive (de Souza et al., 2000), antispasmodic (Pongprayoon et al., 1992), Antagonistic to histamine (Wasuwat 1970)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Costus cylindricus Jacq.; Costus scaber Ruiz &Pav. (Costus anachiri Jacq.)
data.traditional_use: Mucilaginous juice, refreshing, febrifuge, nephritic pain and gonorrhoea
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Luffa sepium (G. Mey.) C. Jeffrey (Luffa purgans (Mart.) Mart.)
data.traditional_use: 'Coloquintidas', hydropisia and chronic ophthalmia, emetic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.vernacular_names: Bucha de Paulista, Purga de João Paes
data.traditional_use: Against amenorrhoea, anasarcha, chlorose, herpetic diseases, emetic, diuretic; hydrops and chronic ophthalmia
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Purgative
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Against testicular swelling from venereal abuse or effects of horseback riding effects and fumigations
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Treatment of warts and condyloma with poultices
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Latex with Ricinus L. oil against worms
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.occurrence: Pará, Rio Negro, S. Joao, S. Anna, Santarem
data.traditional_use: Latex is anthelmintic
data.correlated_studies: Leishmanicidal (García et al., 2012), antibacterial (Bussmann et al., 2010)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.vernacular_names: Pinheiro de purga, Pinhão paraguay, Mandubiguaçu, Munduy-guaçu
data.occurrence: Pará, near Santarem, Amazon near Ega
data.traditional_use: Seeds are emetic and cathartic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Bitter bark, astringent, resolvent, febrifuge
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Lymphatic system, fresh leaves are antidote for poisoning from roots. Emetic.
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Latex is used against warts, gonorrhoea, condyloma and malignant ulcers. Roots are used against syphilis and amenorrhoea
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Sapium glandulosum (L.) Morong (Sapium hippomane G. Mey.)
data.occurrence: Amazonas, near Rio Negro, S.G. Cachoeira, Pará
data.traditional_use: Syphilis; elephantiasis; against warts
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Decoction for ophthalmia, palpebral diseases
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.occurrence: Rio Negro, Amazonas, near S. Gabriel
data.traditional_use: Extremely bitter roots, tonic, incisive, intermittent fevers
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Humiria balsamifera var. floribunda (Mart.) Cuatrec. (Humirium floribundum Mart.)
data.traditional_use: Balsam yellow, limpid, similar to copaiba and Peru
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Used as baths against rheumatic affections and dysuria
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Hyptis mutabilis (Rich.) Briq. (Hyptis spicata Poit.), Hyptis suaveolens (L.) Poit
data.traditional_use: Diaphoretic, several catarrhal disease, carminative, wound healing
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Licaria puchury-major (Mart.) Kosterm. (Nectandra puchury-major (Mart.) Nees. & C. Martius ex Nees)
data.traditional_use: Indigestion, diarrhoea, leucorrhoea, dysentery
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Digestive, stomachic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Arthralgy, rheumatic diseases
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Tonic, carminative, stomachic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Ocotea odorifera (Vell.) Rohwer (Mespilodaphne pretiosa var. latifolia Nees & Mart.)
data.traditional_use: Used as decoction in baths for diseases of nervous system, memory, oedema of feet, catarrhal disease, hydrops, gout, syphilis and vaginal discharge
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.occurrence: Near Rio Negro, Gurupá, Pará, Amazonas
data.traditional_use: Infusion of the roots used to treat liver and spleen disorders, mesenteric glands; wound healing; engorgement of the spleen; emetic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Bowdichia virgilioides f. major (Mart.) Yakovlev (Sebipira major Mart.)
data.traditional_use: Diaphoretic, incisive, corroborant. To treat rheumatic pain, arthritic tumours, weakened by syphilitic virus, hydrops, impingements
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.occurrence: Near Rio Tocantins, Pará, Santarem, Rio Tapajoz
data.traditional_use: Leaves are cathartic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Gonorrhoea
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Gonorrhoea
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Cynometra spruceana Benth. var. spruceana (Trachylobium martianum Hayne)
data.traditional_use: To treat weakness of the lungs, tuberculosis, chronic cough
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Nervine, analeptic (restorative), cardiac, diaphoretic and emmenagogue
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Used for lung debility, inhalation to treat tuberculosis and chronic cough
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Senna multijuga subsp. lindleyana (Gardner) H.S. Irwin & Barneby (Cassia magnifica Mart.)
data.traditional_use: Laxative, cathartic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Used as is Senna from Egypt, as laxative and cathartic. Effects are similar but weaker. Some produce colic. Senna uniflora (Mill.) H.S. Irwin & Barneby (Cassia sericera Sw.) is better.
data.correlated_studies: Several activities (see Review from Yadav et al., 2010)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Similar to Dipteryx odorata (Aubl.) Willd. but weaker
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Cynometra spruceana Benth var. spruceana (Trachylobium martianum Hayne)
data.occurrence: Near Manaus, Pará, near Rio Caipurú, Santarem, Rio Negro, S. Carlos
data.traditional_use: Used for lung debility, inhalation to treat tuberculosis and chronic cough.
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.vernacular_names: Caa-ataya, Mata canna, Purga de Joao Paez, Orelha de rato
data.traditional_use: Bitter, mucilaginous, purgative, diuretic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Emollient herb, same use as Malva, infusion to treat throat inflammation
data.correlated_studies: Anti-inflammatory (Swathy et al., 2010; Bonjardim et al., 2011)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Exanthema, especially that originating from bites of insects of the family Simullidae. Decoctions against Ascaris (internally), dermatophytosis
data.correlated_studies: Antihelmintic (Carvalho et al., 2012), wound healing (Nayak et al., 2010), anti-inflammatory (Penido et al., 2006)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Stomach debility, digestive, intermittent fever, obstruction of abdominal viscera
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.occurrence: Amazonas, near S.G. Cachoeira, Manaus, Rio Negro
data.traditional_use: Emetic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Ascaris
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.part: Aromatic fat, oil of cooked seeds
data.traditional_use: Colic, dyspepsia; rheumatic pain, arthritic tumours
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Diabetes mellitus
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Diuretic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.vernacular_names: Ybirarema, Guararema, Pão ou sipo d’alho, Ubirarema
data.occurrence: Pará, S. Joao and S. Anna
data.traditional_use: Externally: exanthemic illnesses, rheumatism, haemorrhoid pain, and water retention. In combination with Bidens pilosa L. herb, Acmella oleracea (L.) R.K.Jansen, Kalanchoe laciniata (L.) DC. a (Kalanchoe brasiliensis Cambess.) and Kalanchoe gastonis-bonnieri Haym.- Hamet & H. Perrier against prostate tumours
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Petiveria alliacea var. tetrandra (Ortega) Hauman (Petiveria tetrandra B.A.Gomes)
data.vernacular_names: Herva de pipi, Raiz de guiné
data.traditional_use: Decoction: limb debilitation. Against the weaker members of the body to treat cold, and against paralysis
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.part: Roots, juice of pressed herb, leaves
data.traditional_use: Internally: lymphatic system stimulation, diuretic. Externally to clean ulcers, burns
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Against strangury, blood dysenteriae; Arthritis and haemorrhoid pain
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Astringent and refreshing; diarrhoea and gonorrhoea
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Microgramma percussa (Cav.) de la Sota (Polypodium percussum Cav.)
data.traditional_use: Against worms in a way similar to Dryopteris filix-mas (L.) Schott (Aspidium filix-mas (L.) Sw.)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.vernacular_names: Guaparaiba, Mangue vermelho, verdadeiro ou amarello
data.traditional_use: Considered one of the most potent astringents for medical or technical use
data.correlated_studies: Anti-inflammatory (Marrero et al., 2006), wound healing (Fernandez et al., 2002)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: In baths to heal syphilitic ulcers
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Strong effects in kidneys and skin; used in veterinary medicine against dysuria of horses and mules
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Diaphoretic, diuretic, sialagogue, expectorant, antidote (preservative)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Adstringent, use in baths for wound
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Stomachic, antipyretic, digestive, cardiac, diaphoretic. Good for the treatment of colds, sunstroke, cramps, flatulence, anorexia, nervous headache, dry skin. Aphrodisiac but decreases the fertility of sperm
data.correlated_studies: Anxiolytic (Roncon et al., 2011), antidepressant (Campos et al., 2005), gastroprotective (Campos et al., 2003)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Poisonous to the brain and kidneys. Against hydrophobia, melancholia and other types of mental illness
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.occurrence: Rio Amazonas, Rio Negro, Ega, Japurá near Porto Dos Miranhas
data.traditional_use: Roots are rich in a bitter substance that adheres to the throat. The cooked roots are used to treat diseases of the kidneys
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Smilax syphilitica Humb. & Bonpl. ex Willd.
data.traditional_use: Same use as the true salsaparrilha (Smilax longifolia Rich.). Fresh plants are better than dried or old plants
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.vernacular_names: Quiyaqui, Quiya-cumari, Quiya-cumari, Quiya-apuá, Pimentão comprido, Pimentão, Quiya-açu, Pimenta de cheiro; Pimenta da índia
data.traditional_use: Used against constipation, anorexia, indigestion, atony of the tongue and throat, gangrenous angina and gout. Externally as caustic
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.traditional_use: Resolvent, anodyne, diuretic. Infusion used in catarrhal fever. Against stranguria.
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Solanum americanum Mill. (Solanum pterocaulon Dunal, Solanum oleraceum Dunal, Solanum nigrum L.)
data.vernacular_names: Aguara-quiya, Pimenta dos cães, Erva do bicho, Pimenta de gallinha, Erva moura
data.traditional_use: Herb emollient, diuretic, used against inflammation of the anus and urinary retention. Dried berries are used against toothache and prosopalgia. Leaves are applied to treat skin wounds on the legs
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189

data.botanical_name: Renealmia alpinia (Rottb.) Maas (Alpinia pacoseroca Jacq., Renealmia exaltata L.f.)
data.traditional_use: Carminatives, stomachic, resolutive and alexipharmacas (antidote). Wound disinfection and healing
data.correlated_studies: Leishmanicidal (Valadeau et al., 2009), antifungal (Melo e Silva et al., 2009)
data.source: U.B. Breitbach et al. / Journal of Ethnopharmacology 147 (2013) 180–189
